In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define a function `clean_column` that performs the specified cleaning operations on a column name. The function should take a string `col` as input and return a lowercase version of the string with stripped leading and trailing whitespace and replaced spaces and hyphens with underscores. Here's how you can implement this function:

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    # Lowercase the column name
    lc_col = lowercase(col)
    
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespace
    stripped_col = strip(lc_col)
    
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    cleaned_col = replace(stripped_col, " " => "_")
    cleaned_col = replace(cleaned_col, "-" => "_")
    
    return cleaned_col
end
```

This function first lowercases the column name, then strips any leading and trailing whitespace. Finally, it replaces both spaces and hyphens with underscores.

You can use this function as follows:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"
```

The `clean_column` function is now ready to be used to clean column names in your data.
